Stem: Hairless, mostly unbranched, greyish to pinkish-grey.
Leaves: Near cylindrical shape, greyish, 1.5 to 15 cm long, sometimes with darker mottling, fleshy, with tooth like edges near the tips.
Flowers: Bell-shaped, tubular drooping 2-4 cm long, bright red, orange or pinkish, with 4 fused petals. In tightly branched clusters at the top of stems.
FruitSeeds: Dry, papery, about 1 cm long, enclosed in old flower parts, deeply divided into 4 sections, with minute brown seeds.
Habitat: Pastures, grasslands, open woodlands, coastal headlands, dunes, fencelines, old gardens.
DistinguishingFeatures: Distinguished from other Bryophyllum by shape of leaves.
